title: Case Study: Boutonniere Deformity of the Right Ring Finger in a Carpenter
clinical_history: Mr. Simon Hartwell is a 47-year-old carpenter presenting with a progressive flexion deformity of his right ring finger over the past 3 weeks following a laceration injury at work. He reports having sustained a deep cut across the dorsal aspect of the PIP joint while handling a chisel. Initially, there was mild swelling and pain with movement. Over the last 10 days, he has noticed increasing difficulty in straightening the middle joint of his ring finger while the fingertip seems to hyperextend. He complains of pain and tenderness primarily over the dorsal PIP joint, worsened with any attempt at finger extension. He is unable to fully extend the affected finger, and this has significantly affected his ability to grip and manipulate tools, impacting his work productivity.

nprs.affected_area: Dorsal aspect of right ring finger PIP joint
Distal aspect of right ring finger (DIP joint)

aggrevating_factors: Attempts at gripping, pinching, or forceful extension of the ring finger, using tools involving sustained pressure through the hand, and any direct pressure over the PIP joint vestibule.
picture: [insert image of right hand showing ring finger flexed at PIP and hyperextended at DIP joint]
easing_factors: Resting the hand, using a splint to immobilize the finger, applying cold packs, and using oral NSAIDs reduce pain.
past_history: No similar hand injuries previously. Occasional minor cuts or bruises as occupational hazards, all resolved without complication.
medical_history: Non-contributory. No rheumatologic disease or diabetes. Up to date on tetanus immunization.
medications: Over-the-counter ibuprofen 400 mg as needed for pain, up to twice daily in the last week.
personal_history: Right-hand dominant, married with two children. Lifelong carpenter, enjoys woodworking in free time. Smokes socially. No significant alcohol use.
